text: This message was deleted.

I’m wondering if anyone knows why HubSpot took the Flexible Content builder approach for HubSpot CMS?

In my 20+ years in the webdesign and development world, I have rarely seen clients being able to handle (complex) flexible content builders. Same holds true with content builders for WordPress like Elementor etc.

My point being that the editors most often (*though not always*) are marketing employees with limited technical knowledge and will in turn often get into scenarios of “broken” or plain weird design results when they are offered too much flexibility/control.

Our approach is to build modules (including some variance for looks and feel) with fixed content fields. We don’t use sections and we don’t use the flexible content builder at all. We build modules that function as entire sections instead - which in turn cuts down on some of the bloat that is being output by HS).

We find that our clients have a way better experience when they are not able to break anything and we help them maintain the desired look and feel of the website.

What are your experiences/thoughts on the subject of the flexible content builder?

Hi there ! I'm trying to query tasks through task search API, But apparently search API is behaving weird for same filters defined in different functions.
Is there something that I'm missing ? and same quires were working fine yesterday
I think it is better to educate users on how to use the Drag and Drop Editor correctly than restricting the use of it.

I think the assumption that "every marketer  surely will break the design" is false and the wrong approach. Sure, your reasons are understandable and quite frankly there is a lot of websites out there, proofing your point. But there is also  a ton of websites making a case against that argument, where marketers know how to use the DnD Editor effectively. In my experience, those marketers get more content out there, work more flexible and are generally more invested in working with the tool.
Well, our modules are still drag and droppable. However the editor cannot insert sections and drop random modules into various flexible sections
which is super restrictive
Also I didn’t say that every marketer will break the design. I wrote it was the case more often than not
its just like the old editor
I disagree, the old editor is something in its own league.
I guess it’s hard to describe when it’s not shown how we do it. Our clients are not experiencing that their CMS solution is “super restrictive”
well i did not say that you said that, i just think that this is often mentioned in that context in general and i think that is a false assumption, whoever it may have said before
aha well ok, fair point

ok, "super restrictive" may have been to harsh, sorry about that! I am just saying it from the perspective of someone who worked with both for quite a while now ( in several CMS environments), and i am sure that your clients would like the added value of being more flexible, if shown how to do it. Also, some modules are more forgiving and flexible than others, maybe you could use it for some and not for those where the design is more delicate?

Well that is the point really. If - let’s say - the flexible approach is not fitting in e.g. 7 out of 10 cases, then i wonder why it’s standard.

A site with e.g. 50 modules which in reality can be combined in a multitude of ways, that’s often a road to frustration and “disaster”
well it does work  in most cases
that is why it is standard

I unfortunately have only seen the opposite so far. Just yesterday i had a meeting with a major worldwide brand where the open flexibility of their landing page theme allowed them to go out of bounds of the design.
Still talking about the clients where the editors have minor technical foundation for working with the dnd editor and all the options available
well they dont need to have.
do you mean "technical" in terms of how to structure a website in terms of column and row structure?
that too

Upon checking, everything seems to be working fine from the layout of the page to the actual form itself but we haven't had any luck finding the real issue if it actually persists.

Also, is there a way to track failed form submissions in HubSpot? We have a zap in place that tracks the form submissions but we aren't really sure if it tracks failed one's too.

Thank you.
Do you possibly have an example so we can test?
Do you want to put this in <#CBNDYJJAZ|jobs> that's really the best way to advertise work
The zap wouldn't have any affect on submit button not working, do you possibly have hidden fields that aren't being populated?

and the answer is.... Use ngrok
Ngrok is one of the best designed tools I've ever used, one line and you have a public website

I think I’d probably agree that — in practice — flexible content builders on any platform tend to be ineffective for a huge portion of organizations that desire them.

In my experience, the orgs that tend to be drawn to the flexible content builder are organizations that are looking to cut corners with regards to the kinds of experts that would facilitate the effective and efficient creation of web content (designers, creatives, developers).

Predictably — without those specialists, they go on to build low-quality pages and take an eon to do so. Then, they write off creating new web content as a lost cause and only touch it when absolutely necessary.

This isn’t universal, of course. Orgs with heavy investment in creative and light-to-moderate investment in development can make great use of freeform page builder functionality. But I find them to be much rarer than orgs which try to avoid any and all dedicated creative/dev support.

All of that being said: from a sales and marketing perspective, the benefit of the flexible content builder is obvious. When given a “Pepsi Challenge” between a platform with a freeform page builder and a platform without one, non-developers are overwhelmingly going to choose the option that has the page builder. I don’t think I’ve ever done a web platform discovery for a small-to-medium-sized org in which a flexible content builder _isn’t_ counted among their list of ‘must-have’ features.

Regardless of any and all pitfalls that may come from it, the perceived value of a flexible content builder is off the charts. It sells.
Do we have any CRM/Marketing Automation experts based in Canada?
Hi. How long does it take to migrate the API keys to private apps? I am not a developer and I have zero idea on how to build private apps. Need help on how this can be done.

Private apps is basically another word for an API key in this instance, just with improved security measures. Depending on what you’re using the API keys for it could be a 5 minute job or a few hours. Either way you will most likely need a developer if its relating to a custom integration
Hey Chris, thank you for your response. So I will really need to have a developer to work on this? Can this be done just in HubSpot or does it require a third-party to create?
I am just using a simple integration, like I add the API key to the app where I will use it and done.
Is it a custom integration or a third party service?
You can create the Private app from the HubSpot admin *
I believe under Settings > Integrations > Private apps
Ah yeah I've created that, I don't know how to use the access tokens to replace the API keys
Is this for a custom coded script?
Hmm something to do with postman

If it’s just in postman you will need to update the request from using the old hApi Key to your new private app token, using a slightly different authentication method. If you aren’t familiar with these requests it may not make much sense, but the official HubSpot migration article explains this part fairly well

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/migrate-an-api-key-integration-to-a-private-app#update-the-authorization-method-of-your-integration-s-api-requests|https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/migrate-an-api-key-integration-to-a-private-app#update-the-authorization-met[…]ur-integration-s-api-requests>
